author: oaklandmatt
sinaigimenez
content:
Today I got a reminder of how important love and care are in what we do. Just wanna give a shoutout to @Nomograph Mastering for all the wisdom shared here on that topic.

Long story short — I agreed to mix a track for an American rapper who had already been turned down by some A-list mixers, even though the guy had a decent budget. The reason was kinda obvious: he’s got a personality that leans toward OCD, with everything that comes with that — defensive tone in convos, super long mix notes, and weird stuff like thinking a file sounds different just because it was renamed. (I forgot to label one file as “ref. limited” like the previous versions, and even though it was literally the exact same file, he swore the “non-limited” one had a different top end.)

Stuff like that made me seriously consider walking away from the project like the others did — I could just feel the back-and-forth drama coming. But after my first instinct, I remembered a lot of what’s been talked about here: love, care, and being open to the music and the art. So I decided to try empathy instead of just being a jerk out of frustration.

And honestly? It worked. After taking a bit of time to really talk to him and show I genuinely wanted to help — not just as a mixer, but as a human — I learned he’s totally burnt out and running on fumes 'cause he just became a dad. And I totally get that, since my first kid was born a month ago too. That connection shifted the whole vibe. The next round of notes actually made sense, and we ended up approving the first mix by version 4 — which isn’t bad at all. Happy client, job done.

Not saying you should hang onto toxic clients, but it was a solid reminder: don’t always go with your first reaction. Sometimes just showing a little care  about the person on the other side can change everything. It did for me this time. And tbh, I don’t think I would’ve handled it this way if I hadn’t read some of the stuff shared here. So thanks, y’all. This place is gold.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
📖 story time:

Arguably one of the most important things I did in my career was a last minute instrumental version of "I Love Rock N Roll" for an A&R at Syco in the US for some random contestant on the short-lived US version of the X Factor. I crushed it on a deadline, then that same A&R hired me a year later to work on a band called Emblem 3 who was on X Factor US as well. I crushed that and then six months after that he recommended me to a UK A&R who was having trouble finishing a song for One Direction. I did a spec production on the song Best Song Ever and they liked it and used it and all of a sudden I become a big pop producer. Stemming from doing an great job on some instrumental cover for a dumb singing tv show.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Hey folks, back from mix with the masters with Jon & Teezio. I wanted to share just a little bit in case anyone else here is considering attending a workshop in the future. I was initially on the fence, but am very glad I went. 

Jon & Teezio were amazing together. I don't know how often MWTM does workshops with two engineers, but it really enriched the experience for me. It was actually comical how different their perspectives were on mixing, the business side, motivation for the work, lifestyle, etc... This created fascinating debate / conversation in the group. The Grammy nominations were announced while we were all together and we got to celebrate Jon & Teezio as a group for their I think combined 6 or 7 nominations. They brought in a bucket of champaign. All this after having gone through the sessions for said grammy nominated work earlier in the week. 10 / 10.

Rue Boyer studios is actually insane. Probably the best room I've been in.

There were attendees from all over the world. We ended up sharing mixes and receiving feedback from J&T. Hearing and sharing records in the same room with the people who made them with context provided from varying countries, cultures, genres, and scenes was as enlightening a music listening experience as I'm likely to have for the rest of my life.

So if anyone else here is on the fence in the future. Here's a tiny nudge.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Full disclosure: I got a bit nervous and uncomfortable last night.

I was having a conversation with my friend Spencer, and he had mentioned that true strength comes from being around a rag tag group of artists and producers of all different levels sharing their knowledge and questions with each other with love and respect, in search of making the best music possible. Hearing him say that gave me a bit of a panic attack; Had I found my weakness? Has that day finally come?

But then I remembered this discord, and all of you lovely, wonderful miscreants, and I realized that’s exactly what I had here. So… nope. Still no weaknesses. Thank you all for the kind words. I’m a lucky dude. Here’s to another year of learning from each other and trying to get better everyday.

author: cian riordan
content: For mix work, I rarely do work-in-progress checks anymore. Although, I'll usually try and listening to mastering returns in Airpods or the car first to get a feel for how it sounds in the real world before geeking out in the studio. When I'm producing & mixing something, I'm often working on it over a longer stretch of time and find real value in listening to something in Airpods while on an airplane or driving around. Given how tuned in we can be as record-makers, I'm always amazed at how valuable passive listening is. I'm usually finding broad stroke adjustments that I can make down the road that really serve the project well.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Also, (having not looked into the details on Apple Classical yet) I think that could be a good idea. Classical music is an organizational nightmare right now on streaming services because classical music gets filed/classified way differently than pop music that has a single, definitive recording.

If I'm hunting for a recording of 'The Rite of Spring' there could be 40 different versions available to pick from. We need finer criteria to specify which version we're seeking. I need tools to search by the following: Piece name, movement, conductor, orchestra, year of recording, remastered/original, etc. The list goes on. Classical listeners need that level of granularity because the different recordings/interpretations are a big deal in the classical world.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
@Nomograph Mastering said a thing in #deleted-channel (go read it, it’s for everyone really) that resonated with another lesson I learned annoyingly late.

Ruarí: “For years I would open conversations by telling people how much I loved LA, and that I was here to learn. Shock horror a bunch of people opened up and taught me a bunch of shit”


My version in a sentence: “**Open mouths get fed.**”

If you want to learn something from someone, or you want a job, or whatever, or you’re engineering writing sessions when you really want to be writing - people will not guess these things. Get used to asking (respectfully, etc) and being clear about what you want, and more often than not (IME) people will be happy to help you, or send you in the right direction.

It won’t apply to everyone, but I wish I’d realised it way earlier.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
There’s a few questions there so one at a time I guess. I’m just going to answer what you asked directly, and maybe this week I can take a shot at answering what I think are the underlying themes..

**How do you approach your craft now, in terms of attention to detail**

Nothing has changed in terms of my attention to detail, everything gets the same love as it always did. The stakes for errors have gone up - when they are manufacturing 100k copies of vinyl then you have to be sure it’s error free

**Do you reject artists if they approach you to “Master my album i’ll pay you whatever you want” if you think the level of their sound might not honour your history with all these artists**

I don’t reject *anyone* who can pay my rate. I don’t vet clients on a “how will you make me look?” basis, I’m a service provider to them. There are very very occasionally mismatches where I’ll say “happy to do this but I think you’d be better served by XYZ”, an example being someone coming to me with EDM who wants really intense processing - another girl or guy steeped in that genre will serve them better

**How does it feel having a connection to these artists?**

It feels really nice to be trusted with people’s art, when someone like a St. Vincent says “yeah, this is good” it matters to me, she has great ears and taste so it feels good to hit a mark

It’s also very special to hear these things come out of the speaker for the first time - I’ll never forget hearing Nick Cave, or Taylor or Lana in the room for the first time. It’s a privilege to be trusted with their art

**but does it ever happen that you are wanting more?”**

I’m human and can be reliably trusted to do all the silly human things like being greedy, insecure, fearful etc. but every year I get a little better at living a better way, and around the music in particular my operating principles “The why” feel better and truer than they ever have

author: Edward Rivera
content:
In meditative practice, there are exercises one does to mentally inhabit some bleak scenarios in order to invoke gratitude. 

Like, imagine you died yesterday…vividly…the last thing you’ll have said to your partner is the last thing you’ll have ever said, the last interaction with your dog is set in stone, as is the last thing you ate, or the last emotion you had…Yesterday was your last day on earth. 

Now imagine that you’ve been given a second chance at this life, you’ve been brought back to existence and can once again see your partner, your dog, eat food, and embody new emotions. How would that experience be / feel different ? 

And can you invoke that feeling today, right now ?

author: Slow Hand
content:
I know the topic of discussion is affordable earplugs. But I’ll make the case that a quality pair of fitted plugs is a worthy investment. Right up there with investing in the right mattress.

Considering that our ears are the conduit for so much that is valuable to us, it is of the utmost importance to protect them. Why not make protection as attractive and easy as possible? A quality pair not only protect, but they are comfortable, and therefore something that we are more likely to wear when we have to.

Hit up an audiologist to have impressions made of your ears. You can reuse the molds for the rest of your life when you need new ones.

author: Oli J
content:
My standard mix deliverables are…

- Main, instrumental, acapella, TV (lead vocal muted)
- Cleans of above where applicable
- Grouped stems (drums, bass, vocals etc) including cleans - vocals wet and dry
- Separate stems (every track solo and bounced through mix bus) including clean versions 
- Committed pro tools mix session (final mix session with all plugins committed) + cleans

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pretty damn frequently. Producers moreso than mixers.

When I find a record that resonates with me I'm very full-immersion and I'll devour as much of their adjacent body of work as I can. I'll start scrutinizing the record credits and pulling on threads as I see them. I really try to fill in the context around the record by identifying all collaborators, timelines, interviews they gave around that time, published works, etc. I've got a huge appetite for that thing.

I really love reading books written by producers. The more old school the better. Phil Ramone's *Making Records* is a great one. That guy is a class act. Quincy Jones has both an autobiography *and* a book specifically on producing. The latter is a great no-shortcuts look at what it takes to be great. I enjoyed Daniel Lanois' *Soul Mining*, since he's got a very thoughtful immersive way of making records and working with artists that I appreciate.

author: cian riordan
content: I remember the first day I flew down to interview with Eric V. We were gonna just spend the weekend in the studio together and make sure the vibe was right... turns out I got roped into one of his rounds of speaker moving fuckery. The speakers were his giant UREI 813c's on top of these custom subs... very heavy... and only sitting on cinder blocks. He was deep down a Fuzzmeasure rabbit hole and we were just moving, shooting, moving, shooting, moving back, shooting, etc, etc. When we'd finally make a change to the speaker position that seemed listenable, that was always the first song he would play to hear the speakers, followed by Back in Black. It's one of those few songs that's just cemented in my brain from hearing it so much -- like when you leave an image on a TV screen and it burns in -- that's that song in my ears.

author: Deleted User
content:
what are some things that you’ve been wanting to do outside of work life? 

I feel like the idea of “break” can look and feel different to many people, and I think the key is to find what version of those variations give you the most peace of mind and self acceptance. 

Personally, I have a few tendencies and mindsets around break that self-sabotages. things I listed below help me fight the self-sabotaging

1) going armadillo- when in extreme overwhelming state, you gotta find a way to get out of that. I get overwhelmed very easily, so I find that this is often needed. BUT, if you’re gonna go armadillo, then you wanna really commit to it until you feel a bit calmer and collected. Which leads to the next point 

2) sometimes I lie to myself that I’m taking a break but do a few spurts of work because I feel useless not doing work. I’ve learned that this needs to be avoided or else the “break” will be extended into a longer period of time, and I’d be doing little work here and there but also not get anything done properly. It takes a bit of commitment to take a proper break, and in order  to be able to commit to it - recognizing it as a part of maintenance routine to stay well functioning is really important in my experience. I am pretty bad at pacing myself and managing my own mental and physical wellness, so I am working towards being able to put the brake on early enough so that I don’t crash or skid away into a crash 😂

3) to deal with that feeling of feeling useless, I found that doing things that I wanted to do can help once I have gotten calmer by being in armadillo state for a bit. Getting straight back to work from here for me is extremely difficult, so I start with the combination of taking care of chores that got backed up from busy life and doing what I desire outside of work life. Could be trying a new restaurant, picking up a new hobby or getting back to the hobby that gone on hold due to work life

author: Andy Lawson
content: just taking a break from a mix.. i missed a lot.. the only thing i know is the harder i have worked, the better the industry has been to me.. i started with nothing,  zero $$$$ in my bank account (i did have a photocopied version of the pro tools manual),zero skills, zero training (apart from listening to every song i could)living in a tiny share house room with no windows. but i've slogged and slogged. i've always wanted to be the best at what i do and i carry that with me daily. am i the best, absolutely not. but everyday i go into battle and try to believe i am or want to kick someone else's ass.. it's got me to the point where i bought a house and support my family. i think without that mindset i would have given up on this job years ago. The industry does not play fair and never will, but i firmly believe you can play fair. i've never tried to steal a job from a friend, sneak my way into something. i've just tried to be open and honest with my clients and peers. that's my word vommit on reading above.. lol.... Workhard, Think big, Enjoy! that's all we've got

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m not familiar with your work, so this is not a direct attack at all, but my experience has been that the real problem with most tuners is they don’t actually know what a good vocal is supposed to sound like. I’ve taught many people everything I know about melodyne and they come out with a WILDLY different result than I do.

Having said that, pro tip 1: get your key commands for note choice, separate, stretch, formant, and vibrato mapped out to the buttons on your trackball, or in my case now, a row of buttons under your left hand on your keyboard. Makes a HUGE difference in not just your speed,  but also how intuitively you tune once switching tools becomes easy and reflexive.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Had a great experience today of hearing records that I previously thought sounded bad sound great out in the world. 

You know those Latin dance records where the drums sound like icepicks? I went to a restaurant that was blasting that shit but it was coming from speakers that were installed in their tall ass ceilings so the treble was 90 degrees off axis and traveling far. Shit sounded amazing. Like perfectly balanced on some tracks. It made me wonder if that kind of speaker setup might be more common in Latin America and these engineers are balancing things correctly for their common venue playback.  

It’s got me questioning what I think I know and makes me want to get deeply acquainted with a wider variety of playback scenarios/environments.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
This is a great conversation and it’s super interesting to see how culture and geography influences it.

As a Brit, the class system very much underpins life, even now (but in much different, more complex ways), so I share some of @Deleted User’s sentiments as the game is often rigged against a large portion of the populace despite their best efforts to turn things around for themselves. If only we had pure meritocracy here. Sam Fender put it really well this week with regards to the music industry so I won’t go over stony ground, you can google his thoughts which I largely relate to.

As an individual I’m horribly determined and annoyingly persistent when I have a goal in mind, as well as always balancing that with being the kindest person I can be towards others (sometimes to my detriment) and pretty much always in a headspace of bettering myself personally and professionally. This has generally been the key to many of the opportunities I’ve been given. There’s an English word for it, “nous”, which I think is similar to agency but also encompasses the notion of having “good sense”. I quite like that as it’s less about intelligence, and more about personal character. Just my two cents. As always firing off quick thoughts in a session break so I’m sorry if my take is a bit disconnected.

author: Deleted User
content:
I don’t think there is a single person that was smartest or wisest. People all have different areas they are smart in, or wise in. The most intuitive, most empathetic, most knowledgeable (in ____), etc

I don’t really know what smart means, but people that appear smart are very nuanced about the things they don’t know or understand. They can articulate what they know, they can put things together with intuition, they can develop ideas and concepts without being fed one.

My observations of people with great wisdom seem to be the people who spend great deal of time processing emotions and self reflection. And they share what they learn from the place of empathy. 

I had a guitar teacher, he never gave me “real answers” to my questions. He always told me at the end of his version of guidance and helpful tools or some joke (again not an answer)“you’ll find the answers to any questions inside you”. Which was a wtf moment to me because I wanted the answer right then and there- but I realized often times a lot of things that are not factual cannot be answered by anyone but me because even if anyone gave their own version of answer it would not be relevant to me or I wouldn’t understand any of it unless I can make sense of things myself. That was one of the greatest and live changing advice I have received in life.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love this.

I worked with a young artist recently. I asked him if he'd done his vocal warm-ups before he came in to cut vocals. He said "oh I forgot to do them." I asked him if he does them every day and he said "oh sometimes I forget."

I said "do you think professional athletes forget to stretch and warm-up?"

I told him if he thinks of it like homework, he won't be successful. But if he wakes up every day and says "I am a singer, this is who I am, of course this is what I do every day," then he's got a shot.

author: Chris Doms
content:
I think what’s holding me back in the music making life right now is school and my own lack of experience in the business. The time commitment in and out of the classroom between 6 classes makes it almost impossible for me to be able to adhere to anyone else’s schedules, whether that be as a freelancer or assistant. I like to think a smart trusted friend would agree but I’d also wanna know if there’s anything else they’re seeing. 

I wanna use my time in school to give back this year. Even though I can’t do music full time I’ve been freelancing. While I wanna scale up after school, a lot of the people I’ve worked with are coming back now because they feel they can’t go to another engineer where we’re at and 
get the same quality/experience they’re getting from me, and they can’t afford to go to bigger studios/engineers either. I’ve also had a lot of people make comments about how much they like my rooms vs other studios they’ve worked in. 

So while I’m in school I wanna offer my rooms to other people who are serious about their music so they can take their stuff to a level they’re happy with and is pro sounding enough. It really bums me out when I see people in the local scene who are super good, passionate, and hardworking when it comes to creating their music met with roadblocks caused by bad rooms, poor engineering, and economics. 

If anyone wants to chime in with ideas, I’m thinking of offering a free session to students at my university to come record with me/just letting friends I trust into my spaces to use while I’m in class or whatever

author: Rollmottle
content: I manage a team of younger folks in my day job and there are a ton of parallels with music. One of things that frustrates me to no end is the belief that there's a "How to" checklist for how to get good. The answer is there is no answer and it looks different for everybody. I can certainly tell you the principles and strategies for how you might get good. But you need to find your own way and do the work. And sometimes that is quite literally grinding until you break through. People don't like hearing that there really is no answer (and they think you're being a dick for telling them there isn't one...which is a whole other thing). I think the ubiquitous accessibility of information has trained a generation to expect answers to be a Google or one weird trick away.

author: Slow Hand

12 years ago I acquired two sets of custom-molded earplugs from an audiologist and they've paid for themselves a dozen times over. Easily.

I can't advocate for them enough. They're extremely comfortable, have an even frequency reduction of -15dB, and are easy to clean. I use them at shows, studios, planes, on construction sites, and during noisy sleeping environments. 

They're in my bag at all times. Y'all owe it to yourselves to get a pair. Worth every penny.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Stereo. I tried out some Atmos headphone mixes at an Apple store kiosk a while ago because I was curious. I can't say that it had much of an effect on me. Maybe I need to live with them for longer and get used to it.

Last week was the first time that I was able to sit in front of an Atmos setup that was meant for music (aka: not in a movie theater) and really get the full musical experience. In fact, I got to sit in front of *three* different Atmos rigs in three different (treated) rooms that evening and two of them were undoubtedly set up as good as they could have possibly been (One was a PMC showroom and the other built and tuned with their input). While the speakers themselves were impressive and very capable, the actual experience felt pretty disjointed. There was a pronounced feeling of phasi-ness that I didn't like.

It was great hearing these records on a rig that probably cost $250k, but my big takeaway was that they felt disjointed and odd. Even when sitting in the sweet spot.

Perhaps my opinion will change with more exposure, but I'm not yet convinced that it's worth the time and effort. I will add, though, that half the mixes we heard were up-mixed from old stereo recordings with minimal track counts and only two of them were modern productions.

author: Barbara
content:
I have to let you know my first experience with this. Been working on an album that I recorded one year ago. Recording took us 7 days and they still needed to add synths and bass fot some of the songs after that (side note: the production wasn't finished by the time we tracked, so I edited everything I had - 10 songs, none of them with less than 5 minutes. It was the band's first time in the studio, also, and had to edit lots of drums and bass stuff). After doing a first pass, I sent them the multitracks they asked for, to track the rest of their stuff with their producer (a colleague of mine). The next 8 months were spent waiting on their files to start mixing (this was supposed to last 1/2 months, max). When I finally got the files, you have no ideia how messy the project turned out (track names, bounce mistakes, ultrapocessed tracks with artifacts - even the ones we've tracked at the studio before, audible edit points,... all you can imagine going wrong at this point), so it took me a bunch of time to organize everything in a way that I could work with what I've got (going back and forth asking the producer for some files that didn't even get to me or asking if there was the possibility to get some of the tracks dry, without processing or fx - keep this in mind).

Needless to say, when I was ready to start mixing, I was already overwhelmed and tired of it, and I knew I still had a long way to go...

First version took me probably too long to get right (2 months, approx., working on other projects that got scheduled on those 8 months) and I've sent it before I went on a few days vacation.

author: Rollmottle
content:
All the time. I think managing through this feeling and not letting it spiral you is an under-appreciated skillset to master, especially in the feast or famine world of freelance. I've found that having a list of things that aren't directly work in priority order helps you to remain "productive. Having a list of things that can be advancing your craft/skillset/workflow/ergonomics or whatever even if you're not actively working can be immensely helpful to keeping your train moving down the track. 

And sometimes, you just have to set that all aside and just unplug. The tradeoff of taking twice as long on something during a struggle-day vs. coming back fresh the next day and banging it out in half the time and from a better frame of mind will ultimately pay off in the longer term.

I've been on this one a lot on here: if you want any longevity in the creative life, you have to learn how to give yourself the grace you deserve.

author: sethearnest
content:
Does a balance need to be struck? Tell the truth of the situation -- a given person's motivation/confidence being or not being undermined will persist either direction over time. They'll soon enough meet the wall of Reality into which every one of us is continually smashed. And their intrinsic level of motivation/confidence will handle it or it won't. 

You tell a 12yo talented niece she can't be a professional singer, and she'll internally respond with either, "Oh...that's sad...I would've loved to do that," or she'll respond with some variation of "Efffffff that...I'm gonna' change the world," and then she might. 99% won't, but that attitude is table stakes for that 1% that we're all shooting for here. 

The latter response will happen no matter *what* is told to a given person with a high level of self-motivation. Giving the truth of the difficulties seems to only help by giving the motivated person more navigational wisdom.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When I'm producing and writing, I try and think of it much more binary:

If I'm creating, I am trying to avoid giving myself any options. Options force me to make conscious decisions. Conscious decision making is antithetical to making good art. I'm going for feeling and execution. 

If I'm refining/ finishing, or I am setting up the larger workflow, I allow myself all the rabbit holes and options I need. I make different versions and analyze. I zoom way in and then zoom way out and then zoom way in again. At some point I stop, but that's variable based on schedule, budget, sleep deprivation, interpersonal obligations, etc.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is an issue that the artist and producer should be resolving amongst themselves. It's not yours to mediate.

By telling you to exclude the producer the artist is externalizing the problem to you and pulling you into the disagreement between them.

By sidebar-ing with the producer (as was suggested elsewhere) you're expanding the complexity of the communications between all three parties. Now you're the go-between for everyone. That's messy.

Moreso than that, talking to the producer on the side and updating them on what's going on may feel like a betrayal by you from the artist's perspective, because they clearly don't want the producer to know.

I would seek to steer them both towards some version of "I can't be the one to solve this for either of you, and you need to resolve it amongst yourselves."

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Real, potentially ridiculous, question : 

Does anyone else ever sit at their studio for the first time each day and feel like you’re doing a launch sequence for a takeoff and excited for the day of operating your very customized audio rocket to da moon?

Some days I just feel ready to lock-in and pilot my ship, no matter the circumstances, and those are the fun days that make the rest of musician life worth it.

I feel like this must be my version of an experience that we all have. We all definitely have ‘locking-in’ feelings; Where you’re going from ‘life’ to a place where you’re in control (DAWs/Instruments/Writing Pad).

Sometimes mines accompanied by the fantastical. The escape from mundane, where I’m sometimes a Rocketeer, other times a gladiator, other times a grown Man - It always changes through life, and I hope my experience resonates with some people who read this.

I came to realize I do this today, and it feels like a special and powerful moment for me, and if anyone relates, I’d love to know why.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Setting an achievable long term exercise goal and making a plan on how you'll get there is a major key for getting into and keeping you exercising. And doing stuff that isn't boring too.
I've always found doing a little often is way more valuable than doing 1 really intense workout here and there. (this is relevant for progression in any kind of physical activity too, and progression matters because its what will keep you interested long term)
Eating well and sleeping enough is also a major key. I know this is really simple stuff but If you make a habit of these things and stay consistent, you'll notice drastic improvements in physical and mental health, and you won't ever feel like exercise is a chore.

If there's one topic that I actually know a lot about, even down to a deep scientific level, it'd be this sorta stuff, so feel free to hmu with any qs whenever lol

Some of more recent PT sessions open right up and play back perfectly. The real question is how much to fuck with them before sending them off. When is enough, enough? author: Rollmottle
content: I'd pick one path and roll with it. As somebody's who's been at this crossroads (mixing & mastering vs. one or the other), I realized that to do one or the other the way I wanted to and do it right, I'd have to commit to one. And each of those paths imply different studio set ups and ergonomics and mindsets. I had 2 paths, you have 3. That’s a lot to ask of 1 space IMO. I don’t know how I could pull all of those disciplines off in the same space without feeling like I’m making a compromise somewhere. Tracking and mixing seem most compatible from a "one space" perspective. I bet focusing on tracking and mixing will be a relief and pay dividends for you. Your knowledge having done mastering before will be an asset to you in the tracking and mixing phase and make your end product even better.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Gosh, it can be so many things that endear me to an artist and it can be none of them. It's a slippery thing to grasp, but here I go:

**1. They have a well-defined vision for their art that I can observe them continually exploring.**
**2. If they present themselves as a public figure, what is the expression of their persona? **
Is it authentic? (I'm a real person)
Is it stylized? (a heightened version)
Is it larger than life? (I'm a God)
Is it mysterious? (Leave me alone)

**3. Their actions as a person**
What do they believe in?
What do they advocate for?
Does their sense of humor manifest in their art?
Do they have interests outside their music? Do they tie them into their art?

**4. How do I observe them confronting challenges?**
Do they swing big in their creative efforts?
Are they resourceful in how they execute?
Are they telling a story about these challenges?

These are all qualities that I like to observe in artists. Some artists will have all of them, some will have none of them, and that's alright.

author: ALXCPH
content:
For the kind of chops that your description seems to hint at, i would say it is all about tieing technique to your ears. (Assuming, you can already hum a melody on the spot and are not tone deaf) 

I wouldnt worry too much about theory and super correct technique. 

The best Way to get anywhere on an instrument is by Playing it, and doing in consistently. Set some realistic goals and just get going, vocabulary and technique Will come naturally if you just keep Playing. 

Fuck Playing scales and inversions and all that for now. 
Just go learn a metric ton of songs and melodies and learn to play them together. Do it by Ear. It Will be tough in the beginning, but you Will get very decent quickly if you just do the most important Thing, which is being consistent.

I would reccomend setting a low minimum to do everyday to keep a realistic goal that you can keep, rather than a higher on you miss every now and then. You can always add more practice but it sucks to miss out on it.

Start with song you want to Sound like and then you can slowly branch out when the style become second Nature for you. 

Sadly there are no tricks or hacks or whatever youtube wants you to beleive to get their clicks. Its all about muscle memory and developing your ears together. And not to Sound like 4 bar loop, but consistency, and do it a lot. I cannot stress that enough. ❤️

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. The next thing I was going to mention is that almost every file of mine gets prepended with the date: YYMMDD.

So files I generate today are prepended with 230128. This way every time I bounce a song or write a note my files automatically sort themselves chronologically.

This does two additional things: I know exactly where the most recent version will be and I don’t have to crawl through song titles or folders with names like *Say You Love Me (Rough) Version 2.2 28012023*

Instead the file comes out simply as *230128 Say You Love Me* and I don’t have to faff about adding any more info to my file name.

author: LAPhill
content:
I know I'm an outlier here as a composer, but I very much feel the spirit of the question and would like to offer a few thoughts. My job is about realizing someone else's vision and pushing that to be the best it can be. If you're being hired as a producer, then like me, you have to believe that you're being hired for your taste and perspective. So the question is, why doesn't it feel good to you? Is there something undiscovered that could make it better?

I've written a lot of music that's outside of my aesthetic or personal tastes. But if I'm on the project, I'm going to be 100% invested in helping make that thing what it needs to be. There's a way into music that's outside of your vibe - sometimes it's getting excited about new techniques, sometimes it's exploring a genre you're unfamiliar with, and sometimes it's just because the people you're making music with are a good hang. Sometimes, the role of a composer (or producer) is to take their vision and find the version of it that **does **get you excited. We've probably all had that experience of "I really never listen to X, but this one song/artist is just undeniable." So strive for that.

author: popthetrunk
content:
That’s still correct.

APFS (case sensitive)for ssd , MacOS Extended (Journaled, Case Sensitive) ((This is HFS+)) for HDD or if you need your ssd to be backwards compatible on MacOS. 

This is because APFS is copy on write, so when you modify a file it writes changes to a new block as opposed to overwriting the same block already occupied by your data and journaling, those formerly accounted for blocks are referenced in a read only format called a snapshot which give built in file versioning, this makes disk fragmentation happen all of the time - which is a feature for an SSD. 

For an HDD this can lead to thrashing and early mechanical failure as well as the file system getting slower and slower over time due to more fragmentation. But, this is not really an issue if being used as a backup as opposed to active data, however you can’t create new Time Machine backups to an HFS+ formatted drive since Monterey iirc.

author: shaunobi
content:
@Jeremy Klein some thoughts on home ownership... my wife and I have done pretty well on our house. We've got a large one for our kids (3 kids, my dad also lived with us when we moved into our current house, so 6 people total) and we do plan to downsize if / when they move out. Current rate is 2.65 (I got a good deal, and spent a little to buy the rate down at the time - payoff on that was like 7 years).

We kept the old house, and for about 6 months I considered renting it out. I did not enjoy being a landlord, though, and abandoned mission quickly on that. I'd definitely go the prop manager route if I was to even attempt it. Portland rental scene ain't great though.

Prices in Portland specifically... if you chart them out, the more expensive houses aren't doing great, some zip codes aren't doing great, but in general anything in that "starter home" range that's also near a decent school has done pretty well.

In terms of investing in S&P 500 or total market or whatever, I think you can pretty easily see that they're more correlated than not these days. That was the big thing about the housing crash - RE crashed along with the market crash. In the past those could be decorrelated, so "diversification" worked in your favor. Housing crashing? Rebalance into stocks. Stocks crashing? Rebalance into RE or REITs. Truthfully, though, that's just not the case anymore. Nothing is safe 🙂

I think there's also some psychology here. You can run the numbers, and they do pencil out at times in favor of renting (and I do intend to rent at some point in the future, though I've mostly owned a house). However, being a bit "house poor" sure is a good way to do some forced saving. For years my wife and I paid an extra $1k a month toward our house, and had a very low rate, and we really saw our net value go up quickly. It was nice.

One final thought... you often make money on RE when you buy, not when you sell. Place I'm in (which is in a nice part of Portland up on the Alameda ridge) wasn't selling, and I offered $80k under list, and got it. Put $80k into it in improvements (had an ugly small kitchen) and it's worth a lot more now.

Overall tho? I'm mixed. Bad neighbors suck and you feel stuck with them. Maintenance is a killer (3% a year is about right IME). Sometimes you just don't want to deal with problems. But then... renting sucks too in other ways. Choose your poison! 🙂

author: BatMeckley
content:
Everyone’s body responds differently, but I’ve been lucky enough to come out fairly unscathed with my hearing and mobility. 

As I understand it, it’s less about motion than it is repetitive motion. I was also playing guitar professionally so it kinda mixed up the muscles between that and the trackball. I got hurt when I was doing NOTHING but trackball 110+ hours a week for a few months. We were really burning the candle at both ends for a bit. The interesting thing to me is most people burn out their carpal tunnel) which is pointer finger, but mine was medial (I think) tunnel, which was the pinky, from all the chording on the expert trackball. The overuse inflames the tendon which causes it to rub which causes it to get inflamed which causes it to rub which… the steroid shots, some rest, and a lot of ibuprofen over the next few weeks helped.

author: cian riordan
content: I saw this mentioned on one of the vocal production episodes and I don't fully agree with it. If you had a perfect reflective surface that reflected back at a 180-deg angle into the null of the mic, that might be the case. But thats very rarely what happens in the real world. The cardioid pattern is shaped like a kidney and does stretch beyond the x-axis of the diaphragm, ultimately picking up lots of reflections from behind the plane of the capsule. Put a condenser microphone on a floor tom, under a cymbal and you'll hear what I mean. Or try singing into the backside of one. It sounds awful. Often, its the shittiest of the phasey reflections that get in through the back, so it's definitely worth treating. To your point, still lots of value in making sure behind the singer is treated as well as those reflections will likely be much more broadband. But given the size of this space (it small), I'd use all the help I could get in there.

content:
Spotify was not even supposed to be a paid service… their model and vision was never having to pay for music again; and letting THAT be high quality experience as if you are playing records you bought. They did indeed do that, and I don’t think it will go back. 

It was decentralization they were after. the record industry was already beyond rescue (to go back to its heyday) so they wanted a better piratesbay where people can hear the music right away, and not the messed up mp3 that has been converted to different codecs multiple times. The platforms opening up to everybody is why someone like myself or my clients can upload any kind of music. 

I mention all of this to say… I think that’s what they wanted. But I think they were hoping more people would use the free version so they can juice more profit out of the ads. author: Slow Hand
content:
In my gut no. It's a great song, but the beat itself? Hard to say.

That simple back beat is probably the backbone of the last 70 years of rock and pop music. I'm not even sure I would've drawn a connection between *Good Luck Babe* and *Billie Jean* until you raised the question. They feel completely different.

It's hard to make something so elementary as that beat stand out as *the* version when it's been done thousands of times and saturated the greater body of music. Even though they're practically the same pattern. It's too common to be distinct at this point.

I think what makes the *Billie Jean* beat distinct comes down to Bruce Swedien's impeccable sonics, our association with the (great) record, and the fact that Ndugu Chancler has that beat positively nailed to the floor with how stiff and authoritative it is. The pattern itself is still as basic as it gets but the execution elevates it.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Phase 3 | Final Mix
- 🔑 Be Brave!
- A track will have a life and will and will of its own by now. That life is to be respected and only changed with respect and in context with absolutely everything else that plays within the same section of the track.
- There’s no method for this stage, as it’s more of a flow state of decision making that revolves around self trust.
- Sometimes, the gut will give me that painful realization that the snare is still wrong. It’ll be a process of juggling EQs, messing with routers, and questioning if I’m meant to do this lol, but I make sure more than ever that I back up the previous version of the track and push through no matter how I feel.
- For the sake of the tracks life that I should respect more than my desire to finish, I face this intimidating hurdle from a thoughtless place, letting go of any thoughts regarding the approaching finish line, commercial viability, etc etc. Literally any thoughts other than that self trust to know when to put it down, which developed as a macro skill across multiple projects for me.


But yeah - Also what @Juliette said 😂

author: David Fuller
content:
So sound is captured as electrical signals by disturbing a magnetic field (or in the case of condenser mics, changing the voltage potential across a specially tuned capacitor), which generates an AC voltage corresponding to the compressions and rarefactions in the air. This is a whole topic on its own but tl;dr for dynamics you're moving a magnet back and forth inside a coil of wire, with ribbons you're moving the wire back and forth inside a magnetic field, guitar and bass pickup you're disturbing a magnetic field with vibrating ferromagnetic strings... anyway. 

Linear voltage amplifiers (ie class A, and AB for us audio guys) - which we use for mic preamps, line amps, differential amps, power amps, pretty much anything you can think of - work by using an AC voltage to vary DC current flow. In its most basic form, it works like this: That AC signal from the mic or guitar pickup hits either the grid of a vacuum tube or the gate of a FET, and changes the amount of current that flows from one end to the other (usually cathode to plate in a tube, and usually source to drain in FETs). Stick a resistor between the DC power supply rail and the amplifying element and you get a voltage variance because of ohm's law - current goes down, voltage goes up, and vice versa. So, you end up with a bigger version of the input signal, with its polarity inverted. 

Distortion is a *way* more complex topic and not one I'm equipped to explain, as I don't understand it very well myself.

author: LAPhill
content: I know you're joking, but what is the point of spatial audio? To immerse the listener in a world of music. To create a 3D experience. Why? We can go outside and listen to a band in a room and hear reflections all around us. But there is a chance to go deeper with spatial audio, to create something hyper-real, as much of record making has always been. Every new technology has the opportunity to enhance or detract from our experiences, and we have to meet them where they are. Maybe Atmos ain't it, but as someone who spends a lot of time in surround.. there is a feeling to immersing yourself in sound that isn't going to come from two speakers. So yes.. mixing in Atmos can very much be a part of steering the ship.

author: Deleted User
content:
This can be controversial, but to execute C no matter what artist says or wants to do and present it. That way they can at least have a tangible result to compare it with. Instead of explaining, it’s better to do it and show it.

My humble take: our job is not necessarily doing what we’re told. it is to take their vision, and take it to a place where they could say “wow- I didn’t know this is what I wanted but this is what I want now”. Which I think is the taste and perspective factor. 

It is case by case of course and some artists could come in with A to Z manual of what they want, which can be cool- or not. I personally find those boring, unless I really admire their vision and it just feel like an honor to be a part of it. I think being a yes man can be a quick way to become dispensable. But someone who is willing to serve by giving you some friction that can turn into some heat 🔥 can be someone they find trustworthy and interesting. It’s case by case dependent, some people need perfect aerodynamics to accelerate their vision, and I don’t think that’s necessarily being a yes man- but rather about just being the right fit for the project and being someone who is fully on board to do what they are asking. 

But I think more importantly- it’s okay to miss. If they don’t like it - then scrap it or give it another go. And it’s also fine if you end up not being the one for the project

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm particularly keen on this idea of humor as lateral thought. I've got a motto that I say to myself as a matter of process: "Always invert."

Whatever the subject facing me: a problem, a reply in a conversation, an object, a principle I'm adopting, a rule, or an idea, always start by inverting it's properties and seeing what you get. Turn it upside-down and see what that extreme reveals to you, then make a choice.

Often, with an inversion of perspective you get something hilarious, and that can be valuable in it's own right, but just as often you get newfound empathy, or something unexpected, or catch yourself from stumbling into a foolish move. Although, quite often the inversion itself *is* the foolish move because it flies in the face of common sense. 😄

author: Matt Huber
content:
I think the biggest shift for me has been to move away from the “buying a house is the best investment you can make” adage that I grew up hearing. 

In some cases, it certainly CAN be a great investment, but it’s definitely not a sure bet, especially considering what else you could do with that money, as some have alluded to. 

Having owned and rented, I am currently a very happy renter - fixed costs, not being tied down to a specific place for 5+ years, etc. 

The amount of hidden costs in home ownership are astounding, and make the rent vs own arithmetic much less clean cut than it initially appears. 

A great example: we bought our home in Nashville and sold it 2 years later when we moved to LA. The home increased in value quite a bit over that time (more than the historical average) - selling for $110k more than we bought it for. Wow! Huge return on investment right?

After the dust has settled and we ran the numbers….it was a break even with renting. 

If we would have taken that down payment and put it into VOO, we would have come out ahead and spent a lot less blood, sweat and tears. 

Ultimately, I personally view rent versus own a primarily a lifestyle choice. Owning a home has benefits (and drawbacks) beyond the pure numbers, as does renting…and all of that has to be a part of the equation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Been watching this all day. Dann seems to have such good character about everything. It's inspiring to see him play with so much care and attention to feel.

I loved hearing him talk about Mutt Lange's approach and how patient Mutt was with every part. Making the players play again and again while waiting for the right confluence of feel to come together before moving on. There's so much care for the moment. That pace is antithetical to the way things are often done today. Understandably so.

Of course, Dann also expresses the feelings of doubt that anyone would go through in his position; wondering what it was about him that wasn't good enough for the take. So I think it's good that Mutt was up-front with the players about how they were going to approach it, which could allow the players to stop thinking about their abilities and sink into the right headspace for such a long endeavor as Mutt explored.

author: antoniohannamusic
content:
Hey Rob, so I did a video explaining it (using the older version of the plugin) but in short you create two sessions, an Artist Session and a Producer Session.

The Producer session: Sends full mix + click to artist and has a receive channel

The Artist Session:

Receives full mix, then sends back the performance dry (vocal, guitar, bass, trumpet, you name it)>

In the producer session you then offset your local playback by the roundtrip latency, so you're hearing the artist perform "in time" with your session,

You then just nudge the clips back after each take 😄

author: David Fuller
content:
Anyway: uncompressed PCM audio (.wav and .aiff) is made up of digital words generally 16 or 24 bits long recorded however many times a second for a given sample rate, for fixed point (integer) values. Each bit represents ~6dB of dynamic range. Every time you go up in level 6dB from that particular sample point, another bit flips from 0 (off) to 1 (on). The least significant bit defines your noise floor, so 16 bit audio has 96dB of dynamic range at maximum from noise floor to full scale (every bit turned on). Seems simple enough, right? And it isn't super complicated. But it has one problem: you run out of dynamic range real quick if you're changing levels with (virtual) faders at 24 bits. There are two ways around that:
1, make the mixer engine run on a much higher integer word length (like old Pro Tools HD systems, which use 48 bit integer), and the mixer automatically converts the audio (if anything is done to it, including fader moves) to 48 bit. Think of this as adding more digits to the fractions side of a decimal point. 
2, make the mixer engine run on a floating point system (almost every other DAW, including more modern versions of Pro Tools) - that is, you move *where the decimal point is* . 32 bit float effectively works as 24 bits that can be moved around more or less with impunity, up or down.

author: Slow Hand
content:
When did Spotify start defaulting to the "clean" version of tracks? I'm listening to this Baby Keem/Kendrick track right now and it's ruining it for me.

I recently re-listened to 'Blacks Reconstruction' by The Roots and it's completely unlistenable now that it has a good 80 edits in it, despite being labeled as the "Album Version": https://open.spotify.com/track/6cq1D3ZaL8SrrHkgHB8nwl?si=6720c9125a9e40b8

It's not as if records like this ever stood a chance of pop appeal and required an edited version to reach an audience. It's so dense with profanity that it'll never be played in public anyway. Now because of this censorship not only does it fail at being acceptable to a broad audience it's also rendered unlistenable to it's intended mature audience.

If I didn't already love this record and didn't already own an uncensored copy I almost certainly would never give it a fair listen and come to appreciate it. I can't help but wonder if a lot of great music today is being rejected out of hand and not discovered by new listeners because of the censorship.

author: sethearnest

Worth a listen if you're wanting to nerd out on how our ears work.

author: Zack Hames
content: to be fair you'd probably get that result in almost any learning environment. I teach at an audio trade school and they're usually so caught up in maintaining technical things they have a really hard time *hearing* what is going on anyway. They just aren't practiced enough physically to be able to take the time to judge the sounds they are getting, let alone have spent enough time just listening to music on those monitors to know what anything SHOULD sound like. It always blows me away at schools how often students don't take the time to just LISTEN to anything they just work on projects without any context. That said, a gigantic screen is even more of a distraction and makes it that much more difficult.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It seems trackpad is in the minority here, but I won't do anything else if I can help it:

1. No repetitive strain to speak of (anecdotal experience). Your hand floats and stays loose over the pad.

2. Can be placed right beneath the keyboard (if you're not already using a laptop) and cuts *way* down on travel time for your mousing hand as it travels from keys to mouse and back. It's always in the same place, so you never lose a moment of focus searching for the mouse with your eyes or adjusting your grip once you grab it, which adds up.

If you want to get *really* fancy you can press keys *and* use a trackpad with one hand in certain instances.

3. Multi-touch commands, bebe! (swipe, stretch, pinch, etc)

4. Can be ambidextrous if necessary.

author: Barbara
content:
They came back with 10 PAGES of comments, with stuff regarding other takes we might had (I forgot to mention, but it was a deal that once I've sent the files for them to continue production, every take and edit was correct and accepted by all of them, in order to commit and make decisions... specially, because it was an edit nightmare, but mostly because I knew they weren't experient and it would be hard to finish anything if we kept having too many options to chose from - which we hadn't. That was indeed the most polished takes and performance they had, and it still needed A LOT of care), a list of reference tracks that wasn't even close in anything to what we had or could ever have, and me wanting not to jump in again on all of that. And during this, I had other people hearing my mix (colleagues) that were harsh on the way they gave feedback - not criticising, I knew it was shite, but I think it was the right thing at the wrong time for me.

At this point, I was struggling so bad with imposter syndrome, I was seriously considering quitting and getting the blues about the process, not happy with the result but not sure how I could do any better. And yes, I was working on other stuff, but this project was sucking all my energy and mood.
Feeling like a fraud and a failure. There is no sugar coating it.
But most of all, I wanted to make it work for the band. I wanted to give them my best, and wanted really hard that my best could be the best for them. So I kept going, and entered into it. 

Version 2... 7 pages of comments, all on different stuff that I thought we already nailed on the first version, since there was absolutely no comment on those things before... 

Oh, by the way, by this time, I was still waiting on some dry tracks from the producer, to make moves that the band asked for on the first version review.

author: Maxim
content:
To Austen's point though: "*is it okay* to admit that there are situations in which all you can do is *accept fate* as it comes and try your best to *learn a lesson*"

Breaking down the key parts of that phrase — "is it okay", "accepting fate", and "learning a lesson" — to me they are in harmony with what concepts like extreme ownership try to get at. I would just replace the wording. 

It's *mandatory* to *learn a lesson* when things don't go as they were intended to. The only way forward is to accept that this older version of you wasn't up to the task but also that you are not that version of yourself anymore.

Addendum: Depending on the subject matter, previous versions of oneself might view a situation as out of their control but later might find that not the situation but they themselves were the faulty part of the equation. So it's part letting go and part failing forward.

author: austenballard
content:
> It's mandatory to learn a lesson when things don't go as they were intended to. The only way forward is to accept that this older version of you wasn't up to the task but also that you are not that version of yourself anymore.

I like this framing a lot. It meshes well with a mindset of continuous learning and self improvement. I think the way I was thinking when I asked the question was fixated on the person I was in the moment and judging that person with the ~~benefit~~ curse of 20/20 hindsight.

author: ehutton21

author: shaunobi
content: The second thing though is when the job itself doesn't have the "thing" anymore. Sometimes this is because it morphed - gig work (which I do just at a very large scale) can really suck the joy out of you. Here you are working, but you're also marketing, you're doing sales, you're chasing payment, you're reviewing contracts, you're "presenting" yourself to other people, you're worried about seasonality, you're thinking about healthcare and taxes and retirement, and you're doing it ALL YOURSELF. I don't work for a big company (I run a small one) but my wife does, and the nice thing here is: you just show up and do YOUR job, you're a nurse and you take care of folks, you're an accountant and you reconcile spreadsheets, etc. Instead we do EVERY job with zero economies of scale, and no matter how much you try to "outsource" it, that costs money, it costs oversight and time and initial effort, and in the end it's a lot.

author: Deleted User
content:
Definitely something I’ve considered over and over. I mean, if I am too expensive then it really is the reason. I’m hearing this from those whom I’ve worked with before. 

But as you mentioned, you work in an industry that is more profitable as far as my knowledge (games). There isn’t much reason for them to question ROI. I don’t say this to invalidate your point, I think we’re just in a different playing field with different rules. 

If I lowered my price to $300 a song, I’d have no problem getting work. But I’d be making less. And of course maybe that’s what I need to do to get to the point I want to be, but I’d rather do it for no money and have more freedom in controlling my portfolio and having more potential long term returns. 

All of your points are valid points though

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm no linguist, but my thinking is that softening certain consonants allows speakers to flow through the words quicker and with less articulation from the tongue. Saying "boddle of wadder" allows your tongue to flow through the sentence quicker than if you reset your tongue to articulate all the hard t's in the same sentence. It feels more stilted that way.

To me it's like writing in cursive versus writing in print. Cursive lettering flows easier at the expense of clarity, but the clearer articulation of print writing is slower.

author: Will Melones
content:
I guess it depends heavily on scale. $40 a month just to keep the doors open sounds steep for an artist who isn't already selling merch at a consistent rate. I haven't looked at Shopify's print on demand pricing, but in general POD is much higher cost than bulk screen printing t-shirts (for example). So if you're a band selling at the scale where $40/mo. on a slow month isn't your *entire* profit margin, it seems like investing in a run of merch would pay for itself.

Now this is completely different if you look at it from the perspective of a clothing brand, where the goal is to have a diversity of designs available at all times, without the need for warehousing and a huge startup cost, and to consistently push sales to a customer base that's devoted to *the merch*. I can't imagine the vast majority of DistroKid artists are going that hard on ecommerce, but they could sure benefit from having their POD merch visible on their Spotify profile. The small artists I work with would probably be better off putting $40 into Instagram ads every month.

author: Deleted User
content:
Late to the discussion, but I do think the word ‘talent’ is reductive and oversimplification of one’s complex combinations of innate character/traits. A lot of little things coming together is what makes up the ‘innate talent’. Things that give certain people a head start on different crafts can probably be analyzed into different components. While “either you have it or you don’t” can lead to defeatist thinking, I believe seeing them as a make up of different components can really bring out individuals’ best self. 

we all have our fortes, but not everyone is able to break them down and integrate the different strengths to create synergy. And the “talented” individuals are the ones who has integrated the different strengths, whether it was through deliberate discoveries or something that was given to them circumstantially. I believe rephrasing ‘innate talent’ to something like ‘natural qualities/traits’ can lead to more freedom and more useful perspective than “I could never be like X” - because of course you can’t, you are not X. 

Which brings back to what you were saying about the value of  journey over the prize

author: markmaclure
content: Rbass and Maxxbass both use harmonics to trick the ear into hearing the fundamental. I’m more interested in the algorithm used, and why it’s so difficult to replicate using saturation/filtering. I haven’t been able to get anything super close, I’m curious if others have

author: markmaclure
content:
That is 100% the answer it’s just really tricky to implement. I suppose you could filter out everything above the fundamental of the bass/mix/whatever and build parallel harmonics off that fundamental, but it gets tricky adding them back in without it getting phasey. You would also have to be very specific about which harmonics you add back in so they don’t stick out too much. 

This is super interesting to me because the fundamental that is perceived isn’t actually there! So it could have big potential for headroom/loudness if I could understand this better. 

However, I’m also hearing Ruari’s voice in my head asking me if this is worth the deep dive or if it’s just better to just use Rbass and get on with making songs haha

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
There are a lot of people who approach music as a business, and i think if I did I’d be more successful. 

Unfortunately for my family, I’ve always needed to love and believe in what I’m doing, but that prevents me from doing work that might be much more successful. I’ve pissed away a lot of opportunities because I don’t love the music. That felt like integrity when I was young, but in my 40s feels… more childish? 

I think finding things we don’t like in the way others do their business is an exercise in ego. Saying “I’d never do that” is less helpful than “I wonder why they do that.”

If you’ve spent your life building a template, and that template works at a very high level for high level clients, it makes sense you’d trust that. Same reason for playing live shows to click. Consistency is VERY tough to come by. 

Im not defending anyone, I don’t know the situation David was talking about, but I am suggesting that we be more curious, less judgmental.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Cool! Feel free to DM me as you go through this, I can probably both help and learn a bit! Re: comments, it depends on what kind of thing you're doing. If you don't want to be chronically online/focus more on music making you don't have to set a super interactive precedent. But there's real power in really engaging if that comes easy for you.

When I was doing daily youtube videos and really engaged with fans we would easily sell out big batches of merch etc. Friends with bigger numbers per video, especially if they interacted less & showed less of their personalities, had much lower conversion rates even if it might look more impressive from the outside. As often comes up in this server, it can pay to go for quality over quantity of fans, especially in the long run. But again, if you establish an interaction rate that works for you, it should be possible to make it work. You may want to consider how to connect fans to each other more instead & build a community, to the extent you can with what you're putting out

author: itaylerner
content:
2 cents: I think it’s a “stars have to align” kind of thing (That’s why there’s a million artists but only 1 Beyoncé and 1 Post Malone) That combo of unique pov + excellent artistic taste + ability to express it all… it’s rare, to say the least.

I personally think, generally speaking, that a producers job is less about helping an artist craft their pov and more about supporting them in their process of uncovering and expressing it, Unless you’re extreeemely close with that artist. it’s really their job, as a human first, to process their experiences and develop their unique perspective. To become the most whole version of themselves, imho. 

Your job as a producer is to create a safe and encouraging space where they can explore and express it, say scary things, move forward in their ideas. It’s also your job to then facilitate the process at every stage, musically and otherwise, to make sure the execution is as good as it can possibly be. But the artist is the artist, it all comes from them at the end of the day.

author: kieronmenzies
content: In my experience, every artist has a very specific "point of view" with varying degrees of how well they know and/or express it. Sometimes we're in the studio with very specific goals in mind. For example: to sound like the the musical equivalent of the artist's Pinterest board, to sound like two of the artist's favorite artists had a baby together, to sound like the last album but different, or just to make our own version of an already-established style of music. On the other hand, sometimes we're searching and digging and discovering to see what happens. In these production sessions it may seem like there are no goal posts -- the goal is there but it's just not readily apparent. Maybe the artist doesn't seem like they even know what they want but they do and they'll know it when they hear it. And then once (if) you get to that aha! moment, it's like hitting something hard when digging for treasure in the sand. Maybe it's just a rock, or maybe it's coprolite or maybe, just maybe it's a chest full of gold coins which you can then hand over to the labels, managers, lawyers and streaming services while you keep a couple of the remaining fragments of copper for yourself.

I don’t think there is a clear cut answer of when you can’t separate the Art from the Artist. 

As others pointed out the Art someone makes will flow from them as a person, in a particular time in their life.

Do the moral failings (or whatever happened that’s the source of disdain for the artist as a person) change the meaning of that Art to now be something malicious and sinister? Does that make the art something you can’t connect to?

Was the person slandered (not trying to be controversial but I’m still dubious on the allegations towards Michael Jackson) and they didn’t actually do something wrong?

I think that it’s a case by case basis on if YOU can separate the art from the artist and I don’t think there’s a easy formula

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
I like the idea of agency as practice. A really talented artist I've been working with recently is young and very new to the industry. They don't know much about being a recording artist, how publishing works, how the business side of things goes down, or what kind of a team they need to build around themselves etc. So I suggested some further reading, shared some of my experience and gave them some tips (as I always try to do with younger artists, to do what you say @spectrummasters and support them). Their response was 'Honestly my manager can do all of this for me, I just want to focus on the music, it's all too complicated and goes over my head'.

So what can you do 🤷‍♂️ 

This, I guess, is one example of someone who could really do with some personal agency. If their manager walks, they're a bit fucked. There are thousands of other young artists out there who will be actively educating themselves on the business, joining Discord groups like this for furthering their networks and education, and proactively looking at how the arc of their career can be navigated 'by them', not 'to them'. This kind of proactive attitude would immediately gift the artist I'm working with a leg-up, giving them an advantage over peers, with a higher chance of success. The more they do this, the more control they have over their career. It's a win-win.

So back to a more definition-based view of the term 'agency', or like I said before 'nous', a lot of folks could do with more of it and I totally see both sides of this conversation. It's good to explore the cultural and societal effects on something like this as nothing exists in a vacuum, but on a general, everyday level, it's SUPER useful and important to try and exercise control over outcomes. Is the opposite of agency apathy?

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Yeah that makes sense. Thanks for the advice. The question is never ‘should I persist’ - Which is almost why I’m afraid. I feel like no matter what her and I are both locked in, and when someone else trusts me like that I want to be sure I can do my part in giving back in that dynamic.

It’s hard to weigh short term wins/losses vs long term wins/losses at this time cus I’m in the thick of it.

When reflecting, I know I always did my best to communicate as honestly as I could in every moment, and was transparent about every decision and my thought processes along the way. I’ve had many wins, but going a long period without financial wins has made me question the judgement I have when navigating everything.

“Winning” to me is a culmination of things that can be summed up as living authentically while positively contributing to the world and lives of others. It helps fight of the tendrils of negativity I feel coming from so many angles of the outside world, especially in the last decade.

I don’t exactly know what I’m asking. Or want. I’m looking to process these feelings and synthesize them into a new level of awareness as I move forward with what I’ve learned being integrated into my subconscious.

Sometimes being around others, or hearing their experiences and takes, helps me get angles of things in a way that I can piece together for a rough draft of what will become the lesson that I carry with me moving forward, regarding this topic at this time.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Today I had a „damn“ moment

Super young artist I‘m working with (produced and mixed a song for him)  said „I can’t hear a significant difference between the master your guy did and this AI master. Can we cancel working with the mastering engineer?“

I ended up having a talk with him and he came around wanting to use the „human“ master instead after listening a couple more times and indeed noticing some improvements over the AI one. I also explained to him the benefit of included revisions included in the rate for the master.

Some of this comes down to him being a bit more inexperienced, though I still found the casualness in the way he suggested using the AI one and simply ditching the human engineer a bit shocking and also quite frankly scary

I wonder if this an isolated incident or something I‘ll have to discuss with younger Artists in the future time and time again

(Just to be clear, I didn‘t even say that it‘s a downright must to use the human version if he prefers the AI one. I just made it clear to him that the human engineer still has to be paid regardless) 

did you guys have a similar experience lately? How did you react?

(If this is more appropriate for #🎚mastering-talk or #🤖ai-talk lmk)

author: LAPhill
content:
There's a balance between saying yes to gigs that cause you to stretch and admitting when you're not ready for what they need. Requires some self-awareness about your skills, and also some sense of what they're looking for. In the long-run, it's probably better for your reputation to say "I'm not the guy for this" instead of being known as the guy who can't nail a gig, unless they know up front that it's not quite in your wheelhouse.

Other folks might have better advice here, but I'd rather be known for what I do well than delivering mid results. Like I said.. it's a tough balance.
